review.title: Analysis Of Cancer Omics Data In A Semantic Web Framework
review.abstract: Our work concerns the elucidation of the cancer (epi)genome, transcriptome and proteome to better understand the complex interplay between a cancer cell's molecular state and its response to anti-cancer therapy. To study the problem, we have previously focused on data warehousing technologies and statistical data integration. In this paper, we present recent work on extending our analytical capabilities using Semantic Web technology. A key new component presented here is a SPARQL endpoint to our existing data warehouse. This endpoint allows the merging of observed quantitative data with existing data from semantic knowledge sources such as Gene Ontology (GO). We show how such variegated quantitative and functional data can be integrated and accessed in a universal manner using Semantic Web tools. We also demonstrate how Description Logic (DL) reasoning can be used to infer previously unstated conclusions from existing knowledge bases. As proof of concept, we illustrate the ability of our setup to answer complex queries on resistance of cancer cells to Decitabine, a demethylating agent.
histories: in Adrian Paschke, Albert Burger, Andrea Splendiani, M. Scott Marshall, Paolo Romano: Proceedings of the 3rd International Workshop on Semantic Web Applications and Tools for the Life Sciences, Berlin,Germany, December 8-10, 2010
review.COMMENTS: in Adrian Paschke, Albert Burger, Andrea Splendiani, M. Scott Marshall, Paolo Romano: Proceedings of the 3rd International Workshop on Semantic Web Applications and Tools for the Life Sciences, Berlin,Germany, December 8-10, 2010

metadata.title: Analysis of Cancer Omics Data In A Semantic Web Framework

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The Yale Specialized Program in Research Excellence (SPORE) in Skin Cancer is a large translational cancer project that aims to rapidly bring biological findings from the "bank to bed." As part of its efforts, SPORE collects skin cancer samples from predominantly malignant melanoma patients and conducts a variety of microbial studies that examine the melanoma genome, epigenome, transcriptome, and proteome. The idea is to link these data to predicted predictive and predictive biomarkers, i.e. genomic markers that predict patient survival and drug efficacy are conventional, and these markers are either derived in an impartial manner or selected by foreseen knowledge and candidates (genes).

sections.heading: 2 Methods
sections.text: To achieve these goals, we had to build a model that combines quantitative omics data with functional information. Our model includes gene expression and methylation data for seven melanoma cell lines [13]; it also includes gene ontology (GO) annotations for the entire human genome. Expressive of this model as RDF triple memory gives us a number of advantages. First, it provides a way for others to borrow from and build on our work. It allows us to use the standardized SPARQL interface to bridge quantitative and functional knowledge. It gives us the ability to derive previously unspoken information through reasoning using a Semantic Web-aware Description Logic (DL).

sections.heading: 2.1 Quantitative Data From Melanoma Cell Lines
sections.text: We have examined the data of seven Melanom cell lines (WW165, YUGEN8, YUSAC2, YUGENA and YURIF), both in terms of the way in which the data is distributed in the individual countries, as well as in terms of the way in which they are processed in the individual countries, such as the United States, Canada, France, France, France, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Italy, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain, Spain,

sections.heading: 3 Results and Discussion
sections.text: We wanted to show that it is possible to perform arbitrarily complex queries with Corvus containing information from different domains of knowledge. To this end, we have attempted to verify cell lines that are resistant or sensitive to decitabine, a demethylating agent used in melanoma therapy. To this end, our formulated query asks for genes involved in apoptosis prior to administration of decitabine and increased gene expression following administration. We used values from two sets of data obtained from the Corvus SPARQL endpoint, relative methylation values prior to treatment and the ratio of gene expression to pretreatment. Apoptosis-related genes were found using the merged triples from the GO notes. Our SPARQL query was as follows: PREFIX dc: <\ protect\ vrule widthyf: http: / / prelt.purl.org / purl.org / purl.org / &lt1.1}\ drodelements / < < <

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: Our proof-of-concept query demonstrates how easy it is to integrate data from multiple sources using the common framework of OWL / RDF. It also demonstrates the importance of adaptation in mapping non-semantic data to RDF. While generic tools have recently accessed RDF, our experience with d2rq has shown that there are still areas where direct mapping is significantly more efficient and flexible. Our work also speaks to the benefits of using linked data, such as using the Bio2RDF normalized URI for RefSeqs, integrating the two branches of our ontology into a breeze. The flexibility of the Corvus model will allow us to integrate quantitative Omics data from a variety of modalities, which in the future could include cancer data from caArray or caIntegrator, or data obtained directly from the CorrayExpress prophylaxis model, based on MAGE tables that we have access to data from 12sDF.

As a case study, we used the new Corvus SPARQL endpoint to create an RDF graph with data representing drug response to Decitabine, a demethylating agent that has been shown to be clinically active in melanoma [16].

To study the problem, we have previously focused on data warehousing technologies and statistical data integration. In this paper, we present recent work on extending our analytical capabilities using Semantic Web technology. A key new component presented here is a SPARQL endpoint to our existing data warehouse. This endpoint allows the merging of observed quantitative data with existing data from semantic knowledge sources such as Gene Ontology (GO). We show how such variegated quantitative and functional data can be integrated and accessed in a universal manner using Semantic Web tools. We also demonstrate how Description Logic (DL) reasoning can be used to infer previously unstated conclusions from existing knowledge bases. As proof of concept, we illustrate the ability of our setup to answer complex queries on resistance of cancer cells to Decitabine, a demethylating agent.
